From mixed reality to sustainability, let’s take a look back at the roles that have grown in the last two decades, and take a look forward as we predict the jobs of the future in the coming decades. The year is 2010. It’s the turn of a new decade, nostalgia is in, pop history is about to be made (once again) and coloured skinny jeans are quite literally everywhere. Later in the year, we’d see the first woman ever to win an Oscar for Best Director and watch as the launch of a single app (Instagram) and device (iPad) changes the social media and consumer tech landscape forever. 2010 was also the year we witnessed landmark laws like the Equality Act and the Affordable Care Act brought into effect in the UK and US, but what about the work landscape? As technology continues to change the way we learn, live and work, perhaps some of the clearest examples of this transformation can be seen in the workforce. New titles are becoming more commonplace and skills which were practically non-existent to the average employee just a decade ago are now in-demand across sectors. In this blog, we’ll explore this transformation in a little more detail, touching on the roles which didn’t exist in their current form, what’s being done now and look to the future to predict what we think is to come in the next decade or two. In close to two decades, technological needs have transformed the job market, shifted business priorities and shaped skill needs. FutureLearn Category: Career Development , Learning by FutureLearn Category: Career Development , Learning As the world gears up for COP30 and governments race to adapt to climate change, one challenge we face is that we simply don’t have enough people with the skills to make adaptation happen. Here’s how we can tackle that. As the annual global climate conference, the UN Climate Change Conference ( COP30 ) gets underway in Belém, Brazil, governments, global leaders, scientists and researchers are meeting to decide how to drive faster and bolder action to adapt to climate change, and one thing is clear, there’s never been a more crucial time for climate action and adaptation . However there’s a major problem. We’re short on the one thing we need most: people with the skills to make adaptation possible. While demand for green talent is soaring with hiring rates for green talent being 54.6% greater than hiring rates overall (according to LinkedIn’s Global Green Skills Report 2024), demand greatly outweighs the supply. According to the World Economic Forum’s Future of Jobs Report 2025 , ‘despite a global 12% increase in workers acquiring green skills between 2022 and 2023, demand continues to outpace supply, with the number of job postings requiring at least one green skill rising by nearly 22% over the same period’. From supply chain decarbonisation, sustainable building and retrofitting to renewable energy and ecosystem management, recent government climate policies mean that green skills are needed now more than ever to fully lead the green transition and meet the climate goals that have been set. Encompassing a variety of techniques and tools, business analysis is designed to gather, process, and present information that informs key business strategies. By harnessing the full potential of data, organisations can uncover underlying trends, optimise operations, and enhance customer understanding, paving the way for improved performance and innovation. Let’s dive into the vital components, types, and tools of business analysis where you’ll discover how this dynamic field empowers professionals to make informed decisions and unlock the insights to shape the future of organisations. Business analysis is the process of examining raw data with the purpose of drawing conclusions about that information. It uses a combination of techniques and technologies to gather, analyse, interpret, and present business information to help organisations make better decisions. This involves transforming raw data into actionable insights, providing a clearer view of current business performance and allowing for better prediction of future trends and outcomes. From ‘AI-generated’ becoming part of our modern lexicon to ChatGPT, Face ID and Turnitin being just some examples of AI-powered technologies used practically everyday, AI is well and truly here – but what exactly is AI and how can you use it to work smarter? Keep reading to hear from the AI experts at Accenture, a multinational technology consultancy firm, for their valuable insights and tips. Good question. Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to machines simulating human intelligence—learning, reasoning, and making decisions. In 2025, AI is no longer a futuristic concept but a core driver of how we work, live, and innovate. From diagnosing illnesses and generating content to transforming customer service and data analysis, AI is becoming deeply embedded in everyday business operations and our everyday lives. The growth of AI is accelerating rapidly. According to McKinsey , generative AI could contribute between $2.6 trillion and $4.4 trillion annually to the global economy. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs estimates that up to 300 million jobs worldwide could be affected by AI, with tasks in areas like writing, legal analysis, and design increasingly being automated. While there are growing fears that AI could potentially replace a number of roles, it’s important to note that this technological shift is more about augmentation than replacement—creating space for new roles that complement human skills with AI capabilities. title: Study Abroad Guide: Best Places for Education Majors
summary: The post Study Abroad Guide: Best Places for Education Majors appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad is an incredible opportunity for education majors to gain global perspectives, hands-on teaching experience, and cultural insights that can enrich their future careers. But with so many options available, it’s essential to know the best places to study abroad for education majors that align with your goals and interests. Choosing to study abroad for education majors means more than just attending classes overseas. It’s about immersing yourself in diverse educational systems, understanding different teaching methods, and developing cross-cultural communication skills. These experiences can help future teachers become more adaptable and culturally sensitive educators. Here are some of the best countries to study abroad for education majors that offer strong education programs, practical teaching opportunities, and vibrant cultural experiences: Hankuk University offers excellent programs for education majors, especially those interested in teaching English as a second language. Students benefit from strong language support and opportunities to engage with local schools. The University of Wyoming provides a range of education degrees with hands-on teaching practical experiences. It’s a great option for students seeking diverse classroom settings and innovative teaching methodologies. Known for its focus on research and practical education, the University of Waikato offers education majors a chance to explore indigenous education practices and progressive teaching approaches. Universidad de La Sabana combines strong academic coursework with cultural immersion in one of South America’s most vibrant countries. It’s ideal for education majors looking to gain experience in bilingual and multicultural classrooms. London Metropolitan University is recognized for its inclusive education programs and partnerships with local schools, giving students ample opportunities for classroom practice in a dynamic urban environment. title: Studying Abroad Tips for Introverts: Enjoy Your Experience
summary: The post Studying Abroad Tips for Introverts: Enjoy Your Experience appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad is an exciting adventure—but for introverts, it can also bring a unique set of challenges. While extroverts may thrive on social interactions and spontaneous activities, introverts often need time and space to recharge, making the fast-paced and unfamiliar nature of international travel feel overwhelming. If you’re considering studying abroad as an introvert, or are already preparing for your journey, don’t worry—you can absolutely thrive abroad by embracing your personality and planning ahead. This guide will share helpful tips for introverts studying abroad, so you can enjoy your experience with confidence. When planning to study abroad as an introvert , it’s important to select a program that suits your comfort level. Smaller class sizes, quiet campus environments, and culturally respectful destinations might make your experience more enjoyable. Research universities and cities that align with your lifestyle and pace. Tip: Avoid overly touristy or high-energy cities if you’re easily drained by crowds. Consider places known for their peacefulness or slower lifestyle.  Where you live can greatly impact how you feel abroad. For introverts, having personal space to unwind is essential. If possible, choose a single room in a dorm or a small shared apartment with respectful, like-minded roommates. Tip: Decorate your space with familiar items from home—it can become a comforting retreat after busy days.  Studying abroad as an introvert doesn’t mean isolating yourself—but it does mean respecting your energy limits. It’s okay to say no to events or group outings if you need time to recharge. Tip: Let your new friends or roommates know you value alone time. Clear communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds mutual respect.  Socializing doesn’t have to mean partying or large group events. Look for one-on-one opportunities or small group activities where meaningful connections can develop. Tip: Join interest-based clubs, take art or language class

title: Semester Abroad Packing Guide: Pack Light & Travel Easy
summary: The post Semester Abroad Packing Guide: Pack Light & Travel Easy appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Master the art of how to pack light for your semester abroad with this comprehensive guide. Whether you’re preparing for a 3 to 6-month adventure, knowing how to pack lightly can make all the difference in your travel experience. This blog offers expert advice on essentials, space-saving hacks, and seasonal considerations to help you travel hassle-free and stress-free. When you’re planning a semester abroad, figuring out what to pack for a semester abroad can feel overwhelming. Unlike a short trip, a semester abroad requires careful thought — you need enough items to last months but want to avoid lugging heavy bags everywhere. Learning how to pack light for a semester abroad helps you strike the perfect balance between preparation and convenience. A minimalist mindset is key when it comes to packing for long-term travel. Use a minimalist packing list to guide you through the essentials. Prioritize versatile clothing that can be mixed and matched according to the season and weather where you’ll be studying abroad. Some things everyone needs when studying abroad for a semester include: To master how to pack lightly, use space-saving hacks like rolling clothes instead of folding, using packing cubes, and wearing your bulkiest items on the plane. Remember, you can always do laundry during your stay, so there’s no need to pack an outfit for every single day. One of the biggest mistakes students make is ignoring the season or weather of their destination. Research the climate and pack accordingly — layering is your best friend! For colder climates, focus on thermal layers and a warm jacket. For warmer destinations, light fabrics and sun protection are essential. title: Overcoming Language Anxiety While Studying Abroad
summary: The post Overcoming Language Anxiety While Studying Abroad appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad is an exciting adventure, but it often comes with a challenge that many students face: foreign language anxiety. Whether you’re taking classes, making friends, or navigating daily life, this fear can make it difficult to fully enjoy your experience. In this blog, we’ll explore what foreign language anxiety is and share effective strategies for overcoming foreign language anxiety while studying abroad. Before diving into solutions, it’s important to understand what is foreign language anxiety is. It’s a specific type of nervousness or fear that arises when using a new language in social or academic settings. This anxiety can cause self-doubt, hesitation, and sometimes even physical symptoms like sweating or rapid heartbeat. Many students feel pressure to speak perfectly, which increases stress and makes communication even harder. If you’re wondering how to overcome language anxiety, you’re not alone. Here are some proven tips that can help: The more you practice, the more confident you’ll feel. Remember, mistakes are part of learning. Instead of fearing errors, see them as opportunities to improve. Don’t expect perfection overnight. Set small, achievable goals for each day, such as learning five new words or starting a conversation with a classmate. Join language clubs, use apps, or find study groups. Having a community where you can practice without judgment makes a huge difference. Anticipate common phrases or questions you’ll encounter while studying in a foreign language . Preparing ahead reduces anxiety when those moments happen. 5. Practice Mindfulness and Relaxation Techniques like deep breathing or meditation can help manage physical symptoms of anxiety before and during conversations. Aside from managing anxiety, effective study habits can boost your overall success. title: Master Culinary Arts Abroad for Global Success
summary: The post Master Culinary Arts Abroad for Global Success appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: If you’re passionate about food and dream of becoming a world-class chef, you may be wondering: why study culinary arts abroad instead of locally? The answer is simple—studying culinary arts abroad gives you access to diverse cuisines, hands-on training with international chefs, and a rich cultural experience that shapes your culinary perspective. In today’s globalized kitchen, having international experience isn’t just impressive—it can significantly benefit your culinary career. Here’s why pursuing a culinary arts study abroad program is one of the smartest moves for aspiring chefs. One of the biggest benefits of culinary art schools abroad is the chance to study regional dishes right where they originated. Want to master French pastries, Thai street food, or Italian pasta? There’s no better place to learn than in France, Thailand, or Italy. Instead of reading about techniques or watching online tutorials, you’re getting first-hand training in the country’s food culture. That level of authenticity can’t be replicated in a classroom back home. When you study culinary arts abroad , you’re exposed to a variety of ingredients, preparation styles, and cultural traditions. This diverse knowledge not only enhances your creativity in the kitchen but also prepares you for a global culinary career. Your palate expands, your understanding of food deepens, and you gain the ability to blend techniques and flavors across borders. This is one of the best ways to develop a truly international approach to cooking. Employers in the culinary industry value candidates with international training. Why? Because it shows adaptability, independence, and a broader understanding of food and hospitality. Whether you want to work in five-star restaurants, open your own fusion restaurant, or become a culinary educator, international experience can set you apart. title: How Studying Abroad Builds Key Life Skills
summary: The post How Studying Abroad Builds Key Life Skills appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad is more than just an academic experience—it’s a powerful journey of personal growth. Whether you’re heading to Europe, Asia, or anywhere in between, living and learning in a new culture offers you the chance to build skills that last a lifetime. So, what skills do you gain from studying abroad ? Let’s explore the most valuable skills you can expect to develop—and why they matter long after your trip ends.  One of the most important skills you gain from studying abroad is the ability to adapt to new environments. From navigating unfamiliar cities to handling cultural differences, you learn to think on your feet and become more self-reliant. This kind of independence prepares you to handle future challenges in both personal and professional settings. What skills does studying abroad give you that truly stand out in the workplace? Cross-cultural communication is high on the list. When you study abroad, you interact with people from different backgrounds and learn to communicate across language barriers and cultural norms. This skill is essential in our increasingly globalized world and can give you a serious advantage in international careers. Being in a new country often means facing unexpected situations. Whether it’s figuring out public transport or resolving a housing issue, you’ll need to think critically and solve problems on the spot. These are exactly the kind of soft skills employers value—making them a crucial part of the list of skills from study abroad experiences. The process of stepping outside your comfort zone builds confidence. Overcoming homesickness, managing your own finances, or succeeding in a foreign classroom can all make you more resilient and self-assured. So if you’re wondering what skills you can get from study abroad, don’t overlook the personal growth that fuels both academic and career success. title: Best Courses to Study in Europe: Top In-Demand Programs
summary: The post Best Courses to Study in Europe: Top In-Demand Programs appeared first on StudyAbroad.com.
content: Studying abroad is a life-changing decision—and Europe remains one of the top choices for international students. With centuries-old universities, diverse cultures, and globally recognized degrees, it’s no surprise that thousands of students flock to Europe each year in search of academic excellence. If you’re wondering about the best courses to study in Europe , this guide will help you discover the top academic programs, most popular subjects, and growing fields across the continent. But with so many options available, one question often arises: What is the best course to take in college—especially if you’re studying in Europe? This blog explores the best courses to study in Europe , the most popular college subjects in Europe , and offers insights to help you choose the right academic path. Before diving into specific programs, it’s worth understanding why Europe is such a great place to study: Choosing what to study in Europe depends on your interests, goals, and future career plans. However, some academic programs consistently stand out due to their quality, employability prospects, and international recognition. Here are the best courses to study in Europe : Countries like Ireland , Italy , and Scotland offer excellent engineering programs known for combining academic rigor with practical experience. Whether you’re interested in civil, mechanical, or software engineering, these countries provide modern facilities, industry partnerships, and strong career prospects. With a focus on innovation and real-world application, engineering remains one of the best courses to study in Europe. The Czech Republic , Georgia , and Northern Ireland are becoming increasingly popular for health-related studies, offering high-quality programs in medicine, nursing, physiotherapy, and public health. The Queen Elizabeth Commonwealth Scholarships (QECS) offer a unique opportunity to study a two-year Master’s degree in a low or middle-income Commonwealth country. Aimed at students who are committed to creating change in their communities, the scholarships are a life-changing opportunity [...]

title: SparkUp Initiative Fellowship 2026 for Women-led Organizations
summary: Deadline: December 20, 2025 Applications are open for the SparkUp Initiative Fellowship 2026. The SparkUp Initiative is a transformative capacity-building program designed to strengthen women-led organizations by equipping them with the knowledge, tools, and confidence to succeed in fundraising. This global initiative supports women-led organizations across all sectors—whether you’re working in education, health, gender equity, environmental justice, [...]

title: Darcy Business Freedom Grant 2025 (up to $1,000)
summary: Deadline: Ongoing Do you have the vision, the hustle, and the determination to never quit? Apply now for the Darcy Business Freedom Grant 2025. The $1,000 Business Freedom Grant helps everyday people become founders and get funded! The Business Freedom Grant provides funding to help you achieve what matters most: financial independence through business ownership. [...]

title: NBIF breakthru Startup Pitch Competition 2026 (up to $200,000 in equity investment)
summary: Deadline: November 28, 2025 Applications for the NBIF breakthru Startup Pitch Competition 2026 are now open. breakthru is New Brunswick’s premier startup competition — where bold ideas turn into real companies.
